div.head: Programme Of Scenery And Incidents.
div.p: Sir John Cleveland's Mansion,Near York.
Broken Vows— a Wedding without a Marriage—Susan's Idea of Gentility -John Butts a Brute—No instead of Yes—a Tender Passion—the Cousins.
Monti and Lisa's Midnight Conference.
" All has happened as you said "—an Evil Mind and a Virtuous heart— the Anonymous Letter—the Ambitious Girl—Monti shows his power.
Mesmeric Trance.
The Unwilling Slare and the Stern Master—" Can you not shield me? " I am so unhappy "—" Obey me, Joanna,"
Sir John's Sleeping Chamber.
The Grief-stricken—" My Darling Joanna "—Sir John seeks his couch.
The Will, and the Midnight Drink,
" It is done—Oh, Master, what more ?—Is it a Dream ?—
Oh, horror! horror! "
Joanna Preparing the Poison for Sir John.
Repentance, And A Hearts Anguish,
A Major "unattached"—an Unwelcome Visitor—Catch a Weasel Asleep —the Major a Man of Gallantry.
The wrong Pistol— " Stop ! I will tell all "—The Truth elicited—toolate—"Dear injured Joanna"—the Interview ends pleasantly—NeverLose a Chance—the Tailor's Boy—No Money, no Waistcoat!
Library of Sir John Cleveland's.
Seeing not believing—the Fatal Potion.
The Fearful Accusation.
Oh heavens: it must have been a dream—Sir John still clings to Joanna —Hopeless Despair—a Fiend's Machinations—" Hence Viper!" —the Unexpected Blow.
The Triumph Of Lisa.
Charles Stanmore arrives too late—Remorse of Sir John Cleveland.
The Flight of Joanna.
" Out into the Storm—She has gone to Death—I know it—Friendless
and Homeless."
London!
An Apartment at Lady Bedale's.
Lisa arrives at Lady Bedale's—the Commencement of the Campaign— Lisa's unbounded wealth—you now will be a
Monti's Reward—the Astrologer.
"Remember! I'M Your Master!"
The Aunt and the Niece—Lisa's resolve to stay with her Ladyship—a
Fiery temper tamed with Four Hundred Thousand Pounds.
Mdme Arundelli's House in Bond Street.
Brandy good for weakness—a Commotion in the Work Room—a Fashion-able Modiste —Madaine's Generosity—Joanna in London.
The Trap Prepared.
Youth soon forgets its Sorrows—a Loving Relative—" My Cousin "— More perils.
Joanna attempting to Escape from " Cousin Thompson."
'The Cry for Help!—the "Wicked Plot—Charles Stanmore again too. late—Madame's delicate nerves—the Pursuit Baffled.
Street In London.

Susan Jenkins and John Butts—John objects to see the Lions—a rough outside, but sound to the core—Women are artful animals—John not to be taken in—What's o'Clock?—Pecuniary Difficulties—Unexpected Meeting.
Joanna Finds A Friend.
Susan surprised—" What! my John with aWoman! "—Love and Money.
Lisa'S Mansion In Park Lane.

Fashionable Life—Coming Events cast their Shadows before them—fine leathers make fine birds—an Unwelcome Visitor—The Terrors of a Day—Mr. Croker not very polite—the Bribe—Meeting of Joanna and Lisa—'"Tell me, is my Uncle well ?''—Lisa disowns Joanna — Something Mysterious—Lady Bedale's animosity excited.
Lisa Consults With Monti.
" Ruin surrounds me, and you must rescue me "—" Fear not, she willcross your path no more—Croker must be silenced."
The Daring of a Bold Bad Heart—the Forged Letter— "I would not stop at Murder for you"
The Storm about to Burst!
John Butts ina Fog;—Monti and the Duke.
The League Of Infamy!
Joanna and the Duke meet—what a cudgel can do—a Broken-down Agreement.
Abduction Of Joanna!
Susan in the way—" the Sights of London have turned his brain."
What became of Susan's New Dress!
Willesden Lane, Moonlight. The Ambush! The Encounter!! Croker Meets With His Master! Death Struggle between Monti and Croker.
Handsome Chamber. Arrival of Sir John and Doctor Meadows—Lady Bedale swears to besecret—Poverty is a sad temptation.
Lisa'S Mansion.
Recrimination—the letter—Sir John is beyond your reach—he is dead.
The Master And His Slave.
" I am what you made me—A Woman Of The World! "
What Montidid with the Jewels
A Dreadful Discovery—Lisa asserts her Power—the knife uplifted.
The Dead Restored to Life !
" Ruin—I am Lost"—the coil of a Serpent—Obdurate to the last.
The Ravings of Despair
The wrong righted—Lisa's intense hate towards Joanna—Susan and John friends again.
The Doom Of Guilt.
Fate of the Woman of the World.

div.stage: Scene First.— A Landscape, or Country Road.
Enter Susan Jenkins and John Butts, L.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well, I never did in all my life—no, never! Zooka and taters! a wedding broke off at the werry halter.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Not halter, John, you ain't got no gentility.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: No, nor I don't want to! That 'ere Mr. Charles Stanmore's a genteel young man, as I've heerd everybody say —and what's gentility made him been and gone and do? Gentility be—

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: John, recollect where you is—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: So I does—for if I didn't—oh, zooks and taters!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Sertintly, John, I never knew such conduct—he didn't arrive at the minster till a good deal after the time fixed for the ceremonious solemnity.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Solemnnentity! What's that ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Hymeneral marriage, you gaby.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh, why don't you talk good English, as I does—but 1 forgot, you can't, 'cause you picked up fine notions when you was in service in Lunnun.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You are perfectly right, John. Well, as I was a saying—Mr. Charles Stanmore walks up to the altar, looking as pale as a parsnip; and when the reverend offishonsating minister says—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Zooks and taters! there you goes agin! Why don't 'ee speak proper, and say parson ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Because it's a vulgarity. Well, and when the minister says—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: 'Ees, I know ! "Wilt thou ha' this young 'ooman for thy lawful husband—"

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Wife, booby! Then Mr. Stanmore roars out like thunder—" No! " and rushes, like an insane maniac, out of the minster.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: If I'd a been there, I'd a larrupped 'unt wouldn't I just—I believe you! Worms and cauliflowers! -

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And poor Miss Joanna was brought home more dead than alive—and as for her uncle, Sir John Cleveland—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Ah! I s'pose he's almost wuss, for everybody knows he doatses on Miss Joanna—and no wonder, for she is kindest, the prettiest, the most amiablest—

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Present company, of course, excepted.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Eh! pitchforks and artichokes! present company prettier than Miss Joanna ? Which on us ? I'm sure it beant you, and—he, he, he! I don't think it be I.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: John Butts, you are a brute.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: No, I beant! I be's a respectable farmer, a tenant of Sir John Cleveland, what pays him reglarly—measter of the Holly Tree Farm, Dyke's Hollow; and. what's more, my own measter; seeing as how I ain't got no wife.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: More shame for you, John. Do you know I have often thought that I should make a capital wife for a farmer.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Perhaps you might, if you brought a little capital into the consarn—he, he, he !

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh ! I ain't without my little savings, bless you !

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well, and bless you, Susan, if that be the case. But
I am afeard you ha' gotten too high notions for I, and that my grammar, as you calls it, won't suit yoU.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, but I could elewate you up to my spear you know. But if we should ever go to church together, John Butts, you wont be like Mr. Stanmore, and shout "no" when you ought to say "yes."

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: No, I'll say yes, depend on't, if ever we come to that. Oh, zooks and taters! here I have left my farm, to come to Sir John Cleveland's to have a jollification, 'cause Miss Joanna was going to be married ; and now there ain't to be no wedding, and—oh, dear! oh, dear ! my eyes feels as if I'd been working in an ingun field.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: John, I am a judge of the tender passion.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What sort of a passion is that ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Love, John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Love! John! Oh, yes, wench, you may love John, if you like—he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Well, perhaps I will, John—but I was going to say, that I am certain Mr. Stanmore loves Miss Joanna, and I can't make out why he—and, do you know, John, I can t help thinking that Miss Joanna's cousin—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Miss Lisa Selby ? Ah ! I dont like her a morsel.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Nor I, John—there is something sinister—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What be a sinister?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Something evil—something—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh! that be a sinister? What a fine thing it is to have larning! But— (crosses R.) wheelbarrows and vegetable marrows! I shan't get home to-night! Come along, girl, do 'e !

div.stage: Exeunt R.
Scene Second.—A Handsome Chamber. (2nd grooves)—half dark.
Enter Lisa Selby, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: So, Joanna's hopes are wrecked, her happiness for ever blighted, and I am glad on't! I rejoice, for I have ever hated her. She has stood between me and the fortune for which I pine. She has had suitors, but no one whispered tales of love into my ear, that would so willingly have listened. She has ever been the favourite of our uncle. Kind has he ever been to me, but he has worshipped her; and wherefore ? Has she greater beauty ? no—although she is as the lily, and I of the raven hue; and for her disposition, 'tis "most amaible," they say—but what of that! all that she really is, have I not seemed? and so well, that who could detect the counterfeit ? Oh, it was a lucky fortune that made me acquainted with this Italian—this Monti, astrologer and mesmerist! so great his power—were my soul less dauntless than it is, 'twould terrify me ; so sudden oft in his appearence that it looks like magic; and I sometimes deem that he is more or less than human. (Monti appears at back, L, and comes quietly forward—house clock strikes twelve) It is midnight —the hour at which he promised to be here.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (by her side) And he is here, Lisa—he is here, (she turns and faces him—Music— tableau. [See Reynolds's Miscellamy, No. 524. "Monti and Lisa's midnight conference."]

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Thanks! thanks! all has happened as you said it would; Charles Stanmore has not married Joanna! But by what means—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Simple, and, (smiling) human; have no doubt of that. I am no demon, no mephistopholes! but I am an astrologer, can read men's hearts, and divine somewhat of the future. I am a mesmerist, and when I meet a fitting subject, what I will must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: But can you not tell me of—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Oh, yes; you know that Joanna was formerly persecuted by the addresses of an adventurer who calls himself Major Edmonds, and that Charles Stanmore was, by your innuendoes, made greatly jealous of this Major—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes, yes—well?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: An anonymous letter to the major told him that, last night, Joanna would be in the cloister of York Minster.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I know that—'twas written by me, and it was at my urgent entreaty, plausibly urged—that Joanna went thither, that she might hear from your lips the fate that was in store for me, her dear cousin ; for she was made to believe that only to her could that fate be revealed; and so, reluctantly, she went.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: And there found herself suddenly clasped within the arms of Major Edmunds—and that embrace was witnessed by Charles Stanmore; for another anonymous letter had warned him of that appointment, ha, ha, ha! (laughingquietly) and the night before his bridal, too! ha, ha, ha! what need of devilry, when so much can, by human means, so easily be accomplished, while human nature remains so blindly credulous?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: True ! true!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Listen! Lisa, you are ambitious, you pant for pleasure, wealth, adulation ! you must riot amidst the world's extravagance—would be envied for the luxury of your state—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh ! do not look so closely into my heart.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Wherefore not, since I can promise all that for which you sigh ? It may be that the burning sun of India, under which you were born, has implanted in your mind those feelings. I can help you to your wishes, and hereafter you must help me.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: What, what is it that you require I should do for you ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Mere trifles! I shall not ask your heart, rest assured of that. Your uncle, Sir John Cleveland, does not love you as he loves Joanna, your cousin.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Yet why should he not ? Sisters to him were both your mothers, and both of you are orphans who were in infancy confided to his care.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Speak not of the past—'tis of the future that I would hear.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Well, Sir John has made his will.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I have seen it. He has left three hundred a-year to you, and to Joanna the whole of his fortune. That fortune is much larger than he is aware of, from circumstances with which I need not trouble you ; and fortune, you know, is power.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: It is!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Sir John will drive Joanna from his home and house with ignominy ! or rather, she will go, feeling that it would be ignominy to stay—a new will can then be made in your favour —and then—then Sir John will die.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Drive Joanna hence! he idolizes her—doats upon her. It is impossible!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I have said it! but ere we proceed further, speak! Have you any compunctions that may make you pause? Joanna is fair, gentle, virtuous, and single-minded! Can you see her consigned to poverty—to disgrace—perhaps to destitution and despair ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I hate her! and would sweep her from my path.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Enough ! call her hither.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: And you—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: You will presently see! call her hither.
sp.stage: Music. —Lisa goes off, R., Monti looks after her with a smile of triumph—then slowly retreats off, L. U. E.
Re-enter Lisa, conducting Joanna, E.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Why, Lisa, have you brought me from my room ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: My poor, dear Joanna! (kisses her on the cheek— aside) She did not return that kiss! she shuddered when I impressed it on her cheek! can she suspect? (aloud) Dear Joanna, say that you are better now; say that you feel stronger.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I am better and stronger.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: And—and you know—that is, you recollect—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (burying her face in her hands) All! all!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh, my darling Joanna, do not give way to grief!
I know how you must suffer ! but, Sir John has sent for Dr. Meadows to see you—he will be here soon.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
Lisa.
sp.p: You are an angel! But are you not angry—do you not feel indignant to be treated in this way ? to be thus publicly scorned and repudiated on your wedding-day ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: No; I am sorry for him—that is all—he will suffer perhaps, more than I shall, for I am injured—he, the injurer. I am innocent of all wrong, in thought or deed, except such sin as a pure and just Heaven must see in us all. I know not why he has scorned me ! He said he loved me—he has sworn so, many and many a time—and I believed it. Oh, Heaven! give me strength—strength—for I fear my heart is breaking, (casts herself on Lisa'S shoulder—Monti appears at back, L. U. E.)

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (aside) Time is fitting—the brain is weakened, and all the spirits of nature are at war—all will be well, (music, piano tremuloso) Joanna! Joanna! Joanna!
sp.stage: (she turns, catches his eye, and is spell-bound—he waves his hands over her head.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: What is this ? I—I—mercy—mercy!
sp.stage: (her eyes close, and she stands as if fixed to the spot—music ceases.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Good Heaven! what does this mean ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: It is the mesmeric trance. She is a good and easy subject, that is all. On your life, silence!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Is she, then, asleep !

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Yes—it is a kind of sleep—but not the sleep of peace. Joanna!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.stage: (this is spoken heavily, as if in slumber)
sp.p: Yes, yes! Charles, dear Charles, what have I done ? Oh, Heaven! I am innocent!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (waving his hands again) Hush! be calm and still. Joanna, do you hear me plainly ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Will you obey me ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I must!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Then go to your uncle's chamber, and open the old cabinet at the end of the bed ! take out the third drawer from the top, and you will see a parchment paper ; it is your uncle's will—open it and read it—then replace it,

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I must!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: You must, of course!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Can you not kill me ? I am so unhappy.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (again waving his hands) Hush—hush—hush !
Peace, spirit—peace! now, listen further.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I listen.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Take this small phial—(gives her one) hold it upright, it has no stopper in it. After having read the will, pour the contents of this small bottle into the night drink which stands at your uncle's bedside—do it well, and carefully.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I must—I must! I see many people now, and they all beg me not to go—but I must—I must.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (sternly, again waving his hands) Obey me, Joanna! Go!
sp.stage: (Music pianos tremuloso till end of scene—Joanna, holding the phial upright in her outstretched right hand, walks slowly and steadily off, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (clinging to Monti) No, no—you must not—I am not prepared for that.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Poison!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: He will not take it—his time has not yet come. Hush! do not cling to me thus—are you mad ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I shall be, I fear. See! she pauses at the door—and now— Ah! she passes in—I cannot—I dare not look.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: ( pushing her from him) Remain here!
sp.stage: Exit,L U. E.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh, Heaven! that I could recall the past, for this— oh, this is too terrible. Exit, R.

div.stage: Scene Third.—Sir John Cleveland's Sleeping Chamber— door in flat, C, with screen before it—table, R., with night lamp, jug, and basin on it; invalid's chair, L., cabinet at back of bed. [See Reynold's Miscellany, No. 525]
Sir John Cleveland dicovered seated at table.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh, my poor, dear Joanna ! you cannot suffer more than your old uncle by the sorrow which has befallen us. I feel a broken man! At a blow, ten years are taken from my life. She, so good, such a darling—the delight of my heart—to be treated thus, (rising) Oh! that I were again a young man, but for half an hour, that I might bring this Charles Stanmore to account for his atrocious conduct—that I might slay him. To cast her off at the very altar—to make her a mockery to all—no, no, not that—no one will mock at her woe, for all love her—all must love poor Joanna. And that rascal, Charles Stanmore, that I thought so brave and noble a lad—he, to act thus dastardly. Oh, he must certainly have lost his senses. Yes, yes, he must, indeed, be mad, thus wantonly to cast so rich a treasure from him. But Joanna—poor Joanna—it will certainly break her heart! but no, it must not—shall not—I could not survive her loss ; but to see her suffer nearly kills me. My friend, Dr. Meadows, is in the house—he will save her. Yes, yes—It is long past midnight- I must to my couch; I am weary—ay, spite of all my sorrow, sleepy too. (music piano tremuloso, continued—he goes to chair, L. C, and sits) Joanna, darling, pride, and only joy of my heart—your fond old uncle prays for, and blesses yoU. (dropping off) Bless you, Joanna, bless you!
sp.stage: He gradually falls asleep—then D. in F. opens—Joanna enters, passes round screen—goes to and kneels at cabinet. At that moment Monti appears at door—enters and takes his stand behind screen, with a sardonic smile—Joanna pulls out third draw—Sir John suddenly awakes, looks up, and sees her.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: (in a whisper) Heavens! what is this ?
sp.stage:
(Joanna brings out will, unfolds, looks over it, refolds it, puts it back, and closes drawer—Monti makes passes—she approaches the table and pours the contents of the phial into
the jug—tableau.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (in a whisper) It is done! oh, master, what more?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Leave the bottle, and come away—to your chamber —quickly!
sp.stage: (retreats through door, C. waving his hands—Joanna glides off following him—music piano has continued through all the above—it now becomes forte, about four bar, as Sir John starts from the couch.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: It was no dream—it was too surely her. (snatching phial from table) Here is the fatal proof. Joanna! Joanna! Oh, powers of mercy! (music) Help, there—help!

div.stage: He staggers back and sinks on chair—Dr. Meadows enters at door, C, and hurries to him—tableau.
Scene Fourth.—Front Chamber—table puts on at side, R.
Enter Charles Stanmore, R.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: (as he enters) Tell Major Edmunds I will await him here. Oh ! fool that I was not to have thought of this Major Edmunds! not to have sought him ere casting from me my very life—my whole heart's treasure—my only hope. Oh, Joanna! innocent or guilty, I love thee still—must ever love thee! and thou art lost to me for ever. Oh ! how have I been fooled to my destruction—and now all is lost, for how is it possible that she should ever forgive me ? But I will have the truth from this Major Edmunds, though I should carve it from his heart. Let him beware how he trifles with me, for I am a desperate man.
sp.stage: Major Edmonds enters, R., without coat or waistcoat—large heard, moustache, and whiskers—a hair brush in each hand.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (as he enters) So, you scoundrel, you have come at last! (suddenly seeing Charles, and starting) Eh? I—I—beg pardon, Mr. Stanmore, I—I weally thought that it—it was my wascally tailor. The fact is—I—I am waiting for a new waistcoat—and I am dwessing for a pawty—ladies! Hem ! in that case, you know, as I am busy, you will, of course, excuse me—hem ! (aside) He looks vewy odd! I don't at all like him. (aloud) Good day! Mr. Stanmore—any other time, (aside) I must keep my eye on him. Hem! catch a weazel asleep! stwike me cautious.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Major Edmunds, I must, and will have some few words with yoU.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (rather nervous) Eh? what? eh? eh? do—do you want to pick a quarwell with me ? It won't do, demme! this is not one of my fighting days. Catch a weazel asleep!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Major,—since Major you are pleased to term yourself—blustering with me will avail you nothing; and I command your to tell me honestly and truly, how and under what circumstances you met Miss Joanna Cleveland in the Aisle of York Minster ?

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Oh, ah, yes! I daresay! catch a weazel asleep ! stwike me confidential! Sir, I am not only a man of gallantwy, I am a man of honour! The women doat on Jack Edmunds, sir. I am considered good-looking, and they are susceptible; and now, sir, as there are sevewal charming gals waiting for my agweeable society, I must finish my toilet, and you weally must go. Demme!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Then, Major, since you leave me no other course, here are pistols, (producing them) and we will fight—here !

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: In this woom ? in an hotel—without seconds ? it would be murder ?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Should you kill me. Major, I will excuse yoU.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Pwobably—but if you kill me, I'm dem'd if I'll excuse you—I won't be killed—catch a weazel—(Charles places pistols on table) Murder !

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Now, sir, one moment and—

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Exactly ! (suddenly snatching up one of the pistols) Now, stir a step and—I don't say that I'll blow your bwainsout, but, 'pon my soul, Til make a hole in your head! Don't attempt to touch the other pistol, or I fire! Thought to nibble Jack Edmunds, eh? ha, ha, catch a weazel asleep. Stwike me downy.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: One moment! the form of duel I was about to fight with you was just this. I intended to throw a handkerchief over those pistols, that you might take your choice, for but one of them is loaded ! So, now pull the trigger of the one you hold—if 'tis charged, so much the better for you ; if otherwise —see! I secure this, (taking pistol from table) and the next instant you are a dead man.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (staggering) Bless me ! ah ! How faint I feel! oh, oh ! catch a weazel asleep and—wegularly done !—strike me uncomfortable ! Oh-, lord! do point your dem'd pistol the other way, it may be the loaded one you know. See, I put mine down, (does so) Phew ! it has made me so hot! do'nt be dem'd absurd—I'll take you into confidence—I will tell you all, I will indeed. Stwike me communicative !

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Quick, then!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: I had no appointment at all with Miss Cleveland.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Wretch!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: I know I am, I am a wetch—the women all say so—but I can't help it -, I take after my father. It was a note I got, that—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Shew me that note, instantly! (pointing pistol)

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (hurriedly ransacking drawer of table) This is it— no it isn't. Now I've got it—no, I haven't.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Quick, sir!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (running to Charles, and offering paper) Here it is —no. I beg your pawdon—this is my tailor's account, (runs back and rummages drawer, then returns to Charles) There, Sir, (offering paper) that's it—no—excuse me, it's my washing bill, (goes back to drawer, then runs with note to Charles) That, that's it! Must take care of my washing bill; only one and ninepence—but it isn't paid.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: , (having glanced over note) Major Edmunds, I do not blame you so much as I did.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Of couwse not; but I blame you, for coming here and twying to fwighten me ! Luckily, I'm not easily intimidated— — strike me cowageous!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Do you know who wrote this note?

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Not Miss Joanna—certainly not; and that is all you must ask me to-day.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, what infamy! It is a strange suspicion that flashes across my mind—but no, it would be too atrocious. Oh ! what an egregious ass I have shown myself! And dear— injured Joanna! oh ! how she must loathe me now. (going, R.)

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Good evening, Mr. Stanmore!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Good evening! I shall retain this note.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Oh, certainly. Hem ! dear me, Mr. Stanmore, do you happen to have such a thing as a soveweign in your pocket ?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: There are two. (throws them on table, and goes off, R.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Vewy good! (taking them up) His visit has ended more pleasantly than I expected. Never lose a chance of bowowing a twifle. Catch a weazel asleep, and—
sp.stage: Enter Boy, R.
sp.p: Halloa ? have you brought my waistcoat ?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No ! master says you must pay your bill, or else he'll see you jolly well blowed, before you get it!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Your master is a wuffian ! but here— (giving money) take him this soverweign on account, and instantly bwing me my waistcoat.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, I'll take him the money, and he'll keep it; but you won't get no waistcoat, on no account whatever.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Why, you eighteenth part of a man, I'll murder you!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Oh, yes, catch a weazel asleep, you know.
sp.stage: Music—Major Edmunds chases Boy, who after a run, slips down, crawls between the Major'S legs, and upsets him— Boy bolts off— Major scrambles up and follows, shouting.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: My waistcoat! I want my waistcoat! catch a weazel—

div.stage: Scene Fifth.—Library at Sir John Cleveland's.
Sir John discovered, in large easy chair, c, he, is ill, and care-worn—Dr. Meadows standing near him, door L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh, heaven help me! this is terrible! But are you sure, doctor, are you sure ?

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Too certain, my friend. You remember that you asked me for some poison to give Carlos, your poor old spaniel, to put it out of the pain it has so long suffered ?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: (faintly) Yes, yes—and—

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: I gave the dog a little of your night drink from the glass in which you saw her pour the poison—a very little! then a sharp convulsion passed through its body, and it was dead.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh, Heaven help me! and she—Joanna, Joanna—my own dear one—she whom I loved so well—the child of my heart! Heaven have mercy upon me ! Oh, Joanna— Joanna!
sp.stage: Enter Lisa Selby, R.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Uncle, what is it? what has happened ! why do you mention dear Joanna's name with such grief? Is she ill? let me at once fly to her! poor Joanna!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Lisa, I am very unhappy; and when I tell you—

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir John, (aside to him) What is to be done can be done by you and me! precious secrets keep best in the fewest hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: I believe you are right, my dear doctor. Go to your room, Lisa, and think nothing more of it—go, go.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Adieu, dear uncle ; but pray let me know if poor Joanna should be worse, (aside) Curse the officious meddler.
sp.stage: Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Lisa has a good heart—I see it plainly now. Doctor, I have been unjust to her.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Umph! perhaps!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: I have liked her but little—

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: And I have liked her not at all; and yet I know not why ; but even now there is something that—
sp.stage: Enter Joanna, R.—Sir John starts to his feet and gazes on her trembling.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Dear uncle, you are not well!

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: And you, Joanna—how pale you are!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It may be, for I am weak and suffering; but I shall soon be better, dear uncle, if you will not grieve.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Great Heaven! , Oh, it must have been a dream, or I am mad. It is not possible—my own darling Joanna, that I for so many years doated on—that I have ever kept next my heart! no, no! Oh, anything but that—it is not in nature— no, no, doctor, I will not believe it though the world said— Oh, Heaven help me—I shall go quite mad.
sp.stage: sinks sobbing into chair.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Dear uncle, I see it but too plainly—you cannot rest for the thought of that dreadful moment at the Cathedral, when he, whom I was to wed and to love, scorned and rejected me; but time will soothe even that sorrow. I suffer now. Heaven knows I do ; but I will stay with you, and we will be happy in loving each other. I will be to you as a loving child, and you to me as a dear father, to whom I will owe all of joy the world can give me.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: (choking with emotion) Take her away—oh, take her away.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Uncle! you cast me from you!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: No, no—Heaven help me, no. To my arms—to my arms—to my heart, my dear child. I will mistrust my senses — I will believe my eyes have played me false—I love you still! kill me—do as you please—I cannot help loving you ever—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Dear uncle! (about to embrace him—Dr. Meadows interposes.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: No, this must not be—it is exoneration—it is justification that is wanted—not weakness. (Sir John sinks into chair)

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: What, oh, what is it that you mean, dear sir ?

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Old friend, you must be firm now, and act as doth become a man. Go, Joanna, go!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, no no; surely my place is here if my dear uncle is ill! I know not the meaning of all that I see and hear —you both speak in riddles to me; but that cannot change my affection for my dear uncle, and I will stay with him. (clinging to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p:
(rising and shaking her off) Fiend! viper! that I have nourished in my bosom ! Monster! that with the face of an angel conceals the heart of a murderess! I cast you from
me—you abide not longer beneath this roof. You shall not starve, for that would be to tempt you to commit more crime ; you are my dear sister's child, and I cannot forget that I did love you—too much—oh, too much I loved yoU. Hence— hence! and carry with you the consciousness that you have lost all you would have grasped at by my murder.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (aghast) Uncle !

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Poisoner! go, go! I cast you for ever from me. Heaven will perhaps have mercy on me, and soon take me from a world I have lost all hope in. May He, too, forgive you! Why did you do this dreadful deed ? Oh, my poor heart and brain! go, go, viper and wretch—hence, and carry with you your shame and your disgrace, (sinks into chair) A fiend has taken the likeness of my child. Go, go!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Is it a dream, or is he mad? Yes, I will go—I will go! (casts a tender and sorrowful look on Sir John, and is slowly going, R.)

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Joanna, I can but pity you! Say—oh, say that you repent—that you are penitent.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (bewildered) Penitent! repent!

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Yes; do not harden your heart. Own that you sought to poison your uncle—that so you might render quickly effective the will in which you saw he had left you nearly all! own that all this results from a criminal connection with Major Edmunds—own it all, and seek mercy an forgiveness—here and hereafter.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Mercy—mercy! Oh, you are unmerciful—you seek to drive me mad. What have I to do with wills and poisonings ? Heaven help me, and attest my innocence, for as I live and breathe, I swear I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: This is too much!.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: (wildly) I saw you, and had rather you had plucked out my poor old eyes than shown them such a sight. It kills me even to look upon you ! Go, wretch—go from me at once and for ever.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I am innocent of all that is alleged against me— the time will probably come when you, uncle, will find that it is so! Heaven send that it may not be too late, (suddenly snatches Sir John's hand, kisses it) Farewell! Heaven blesa you, uncle, for all your past goodness to me—farewell! Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Oh, surely innocence only could look like that; and yet—Sir John—Sir John! (going to him) On your soul—on all your hopes in Heaven, are you certain you saw her place the poison in your drink ?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: On my soul—yes! as I hope for Heaven—yes! (thunder heard—wind and rain) Hark! Heaven itself is speaking now against her!

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: It is a fearful night!
sp.stage: Charles Stanmore hurries on, L. U. E.
sp.p: Mr. Stanmore!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis he has been the cause of all. (rising) Come you to gloat upon the ruin you have made ?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: No—oh, no—Joanna is innocent! it was on an errand of kindness that she went that night to the Cathedral. I have got the truth from that man, Edmunds. She is as true as light! my eyes played me false! for did I not see her in the Cathedral with that man ? and yet she is innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Ah! if—if it could be ! Doctor, tell him all—

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: (to Charles) On a solemn promise of secrecy—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I swear ; but—

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Listen ! (takes him a little up, and speaks to him)

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh, good Heaven! If, after all, it were possible that she is innocent! the joy of it would more surely kill me than the agony I now endure. Oh, how gladly could I die if it were proved that she is still worthy of my love, (sits)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: (coming forward) No, no, it is not—and it cannot—'tis most horrible ; but even this is susceptible of some explanation. What, if her brain disordered, her spirits sunk, she arose in her sleep, and did this, not knowing her own acts ?

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: (exclaiming) Ah ! that is a new light—fool that I was not to think of that!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: (starting to his feet) My child! my Joanna! my darling! (sobbing) I must—I will see her again—my innocent —my own dove—my beautiful! (is hurrying off, but is stayed by Dr. Meadows—thunder, wind, and rain) Let me go! you shall not hold me! let me go! Joanna—Joanna—my love—my own dear Joanna!
sp.stage: Enter Lisa, R.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: She has gone—has fled from the house. (Sir John is transfixed.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, Heaven! and on such a night as this! instant pursuit—

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: She has gone to death, I know—I feel it—she could not survive the loss of her uncle's love. Joanna, my darling— my only hope on earth—I have destroyed thee!

div.stage: (Music—sinks despairingly on his knees, C.—Dr. Meadows hurries to him—Stanmore stands despairingly, L.—Monti suddenly appears at back, from L. U. E., and he and Lisa exchange glances of triumph—thunder, wind, and rain— music and tableau
Scene First.—London—an Apartment at Lady Bedale's. (2nd grooves.
Enter Lisa and Monti, L.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: So, Lisa, you are now in London, at the house of Lady Bedale.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes! By your advice, I persuaded my uncle to permit me to come to London, that I might search for poor Joanna.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: That search shall be prosecuted by me, and I will find her, doubt not, for that she is in London, I am well convinced ; and 'tis necessary to our schemes that she should be within my power.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh, yes—for she found, I could no longer remain here.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Could not live that gay—that joyous, aristocratic life for which you have dared so much.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ay, truly; and when revelling amidst luxury and splendour, I shall be well repaid for all that in my sin I have suffered—shall be happy, shall I not ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (smiling sarcastically) Oh, certainly !

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh, I will at once commence a life of wild and glorious excitement. You assure me I have the means!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Oh, yes, if you have not neglected the credentials with which I bade you furnish yourself ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I have them all. First a letter to this Lady Bedale, Sir John's sister-in-law, whom 'tis long since he saw, and whom he greatly dislikes—you have fully instructed me respecting her—and I shall well know how to act when we encounter.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Good! go on!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Next a letter to one Mr. Croker, Sir John's town solicitor, who is to advise me and aid in the search for Joanna.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: That letter you will not deliver—that letter would ruin our every hope.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I understand that; and lastly—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Lastly, I hope you prevailed on Sir John, as I directed, to afford you means of drawing on his banker for whatever sums you might need.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes, I have here an authorisation to Messrs. Coutts to honour all drafts signed by Lisa Selby.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Good; and that paper places four hundred and twenty thousand pounds at your entire disposal.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (amazed and gasping) Four hundred and—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Your uncle, Sir John Cleveland, owing to having had two large West Indian Estates left to him, and a manor in Rutlandshire worth thirty thousand a-year, is one of the richest commoners in England.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: And that enormous sum then may be mine ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Absolutely! You will be a princess—a queen— every pleasure that wealth can purchase will be yours—every enjoyment will you know that sense can find; if you will but be what you must be, in order thoroughly to enjoy what is offered to you—if, in short, you will be—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: What—what?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: A Woman of the World!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I will—I will! I feel that I was born for joy—for power—I—I—oh, my brain grows dizzy at the mere thought of such delight.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: What I promised I have so far accomplished—your rival is swept from your path—now 'tis your turn to act. Prepare yourself for the glorious part you have to play.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: And—and you—what am I to repay you for all this aid—for all this brightening future ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Oh, I shall want some money; and further, you must obtain, by any means, all the valuable jewels you can possibly become possessed of, and give them into my keeping for four-and-twenty hours only—at the end of which time they shall be returned to yoU.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Really and intact, as I receive them.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: And your purpose with them! I cannot understand—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: It is not necessary that you should—nor need you fear—I but want them that I may work certain spells.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: It is a disagreeable and a difficult command that you have given me.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: But one which you must perforce obey. I have served you hitherto; but remember, if need be, I am your master.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know and tremble at the knowledge.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Conform to my wishes, and you have naught to fear. Jewellers will send their stores to be approved by so wealthy a lady—you will have, too, jewelled friends; borrow, or if no other way presents itself, steal—anything rather than dare to disobey my commands.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: What say you ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: It is not, surely, much that I ask in return for the wealth and splendour with which I have furnished yoU.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I will do as you wish.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I am sure of it. You know where I may be found, should you desire to see, or send for me; and so, for awhile, adieu ! Lady Bedale will presently be with you, and so I leave yoU. Fear nothing—that which I undertake, I carry out. I can divine the future—can read it as in a glass—and I predict for you a bright and glorious career.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: But—but the end of all this enjoyment—the end—is there nothing to dread then ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: The end will be dust—that will be the end of you— of me—and of all that live and breathe in the great world; but until that end comes, let us enjoy the cup of happiness that fortune offers to our lips. Farewell! Music.—Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: A new career has commenced for me, and at every hazard, I will pursue it.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Bedale, R.
sp.p: I presume that I have the honour to address the Countess of Bedale ? (Lady Bedale slightly bows) This note from Sir John Cleveland will explain the cause of my presence here.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (taking note) Oh, indeed! pray sit down (holding note in right hand, and pointing to chair with left hand. Music —tableau. [No. 521, " Lisa visits the Countess of Bedale."] a moment, (putting glass her eye and glancing over note) Ah, well—really—cool; but I have no further expectations from Sir John, and do not see why I should be burthened with his niece.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Polite—very.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Therefore, Miss—a—a—Miss—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Selby!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Miss Wigby—you see—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Selby!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ah, exactly!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p:
I do not ask much of you, madam—(smiling) a home with you, and such introductions as may make a season in London
agreeable to me ; your Ladyship's rank, I presume, opens for you those circles in which I wish to move ?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: And so, madam, I throw myself entirely upon you, for your protection, advice—assistance—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well, upon my word, Miss Swilsby—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Selby!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Selby—precisely—it seems that I must be excessively plain—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh, you are, indeed, madam—remarkably plain.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (staggering back) Ah! ah!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: You are ungrateful! for you have been under great obligations to Sir John; but no matter, I am resolved to stay here; I like you too well to part with you—you have no gratitude—no attachment. You are a countess, and you are poor.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well I never—no—in all my life I never did— hark'ye, Miss Jigby!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Selby!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well, Wigby—you are the most audacious—but I'll soon settle this, (calling) Jane! run for a policeman.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Do not be silly, madam, for I intend to stay, and pay yoU.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Pay me, Miss Slugsby! I hate the very name of pay ! I never pay anybody.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (slowly) At my disposal I have four hundred thousand pounds!
sp.stage: Lady Bedale utters a scream of astonishment, staggers back, and falls on sofa.
Enter Jane, R.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Did you call, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Get out! (starts suddenly to her feet, snatching up sofa pillow and throws it at Jane's head, who runs off screaming, R. and you have—really—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Four hundred thousand pounds ; which I fondly hoped the Countess of Bedale would have helped a poor country girl to expend, by introducing her to the ranks of fashion and extravagance.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (rushing to Lisa, and embracing her) Oh! my dear, my beautiful niece! Four hundred thousand pounds! why I will make you the centre of fashion—your name shall be on every lip! Your beauty—my dear, you really are good looking—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p:
(smiling) Yes, I have four hundred thousand charms. Aid me to attain my wishes, and you shall be no longer poor
Lady Bedale. To-morrow, to begin with, I will give you a cheque for five thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (embracing Lisa again) Oh, you blessed angel! Miss Selby, my love, I adore you ! I can, and will help you to all you desire; and if in London society, you wish to be considered the arbitress of fashion—as the—the star of society —I can shew you how to be so.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Good! I would taste of every enjoyment.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You seek pleasure?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ay, and power.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But you must have no nonsensical scruples.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Do not fear me.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You must be, in short—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: A thorough Woman of the World—I will! Exeunt R.

div.stage: Scene Second —Madame Arundelli's Sanctum. Large window in flat, looking on to street—(3rd grooves)—table, chairs, &c.
Madame Arundelli discovered seated, and drinking from wine glass, a decanter of brandy beside her. Enter Miss Winch, R.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (starts, and is nearly choked) Eh—what's that? how you made me jump—and the bran—hem ! the cordial has gone the wrong way. I felt so weak and faint, Winch, that I was obliged to take a little of my reviving cordial.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: (aside) Brandy, I know, (aloud) Yes, mum, you is delicate—you looks so ; but I came to say, mum, that there is a great commotion in the work-room ; the girls say they are overworked and underpaid.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (rising) Ungrateful hussies! and we have a housefull of work! Oh, who would be a fashionable milliner ? Overworked, indeed! Why, in the very busiest season I never keep them at it, more than nineteen hours, out of the twenty- four—and at present they are only working eighteen hours— and underpaid, forsooth ! don't I allow them the liberal sum of a shilling a day? What would the ungrateful wretches have?

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Very true, mum. Ah, it's a wicked world! there's that girl, Simpson, who is continually presuming to say that she is very ill, has this morning, already, mum—had the outrageous impudence to faint away three times—actually went right off, over her work, mum.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p:
To faint away in working hours ! Never heard of such audacity in all my life ! her time belongs to me,
and it's a robbery ! Why couldn't the hussey wait till she got home ? This won't do, Winch!

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: No, mum—it won't.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Bundle her off—lead her down stairs, and place her in the street—no doubt she will get home somehow ; that is, if she has got a home to go to; if not, there is the workhouse, and other benevolent institutions—only make haste and get her out of the house, or she may pretend to be worse, and I may be put to the expense of a cab ; and that wouldn't do, for I know she comes about four miles to work.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: And, of course, she ain't to have none of her day's wages—she ain't been here this morning above seven hours.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Umph! not half a day! Well, never mind, let her have sixpence—I never can help being generous.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: (going) No, that you can't, mum.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Stay, Winch ; has my niece risen yet?

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Yes, mum. And there's another noble act of yours—to give a shelter to the poor, discarded, houseless thing—ah ! you are too good for this world !

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: I hope not, Winch, for I am not tired of it yet, though mine is a harrassing life, and I often need a little comfort.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: (aside) Brandy—hem! (aloud) but you are rich and— -

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Yes, a good and virtuous life ever meets with its reward. I should not, though, have been burthened with a niece I never saw before in all my life, but a glance shewed me that the girl is very pretty, and the Duke of Endell is very liberal—he will provide handsomely for her, and it is our duty, you know, to do our best for our relations—so if she should take his fancy—

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: He will be certain, mum, to reward you well.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: I have never found him niggardly, and I shall not fail to reward you, Winch.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Thank you, mum!

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: It is a duty one owes to oneself to neglect no honest means of adding to one's little store ; but honestly, of course, always honestly and properly.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Of course mum, not otherwise—certainly not, mum.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: And now send my niece to me, Winch.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: (going) Yes, mum!

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: And, Winch?

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: (returning) Mum?

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Recollect, that to my niece, the Duke of Endell will be my cousin—Cousin Thompson. The girl is fresh from the country, and might, perhaps, prove a little squeamish.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: I shall remember, mum. Exit L.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Stop! let me put away this bran—hem! my cordial! (does so) The duke will presently be here, and—
sp.stage: Enter Joanna, L,.—she is handsomely dressed.
sp.p: Well, Joanna—that, you tell me, is your name, you are looking charmingly this morning.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I was fatigued in mind and body, and I slept well, and long.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Ah! youth soon forgets its sorrows—and so your name is Arundel, although you have always been called Cleveland ; and you are, it seems, the daughter of my dead brother, Captain Arundel. My brother never countenanced me—but never mind that; you have told me your story—I own I cannot exactly understand why you have left Sir John Cleveland's—but as I said before, never mind that.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: He is no longer kind to me—he no longer has faith in me ; and so I have left him and come up to London to you, as my only relative, to throw myself upon your kindness.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Ah, exactly—and had some trouble to find me, no doubt ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Yes, I knew not your address ; and your change of name—

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Exactly—from Arundel to Arundelli, my dear 'Twas necessary—nothing that's native is fashionable—must be foreign to succeed in London—but really your arrival—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I can labour! You employ other young girls— I can work ; I do not want to be a burden to you—I wish to work for you, that is all; and if you can give me kindness as well, I shall look upon it as a precious boon.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Oh, we don't want any hands.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: But you will not cast me from you ? For his sake who sleeps in the grave now, and for the dear love that may yet be all our own, when we meet again after this world's trials and fitful frowns have passed away, oh, do not abandon me in this great and merciless city! Oh, do not, I implore you! for, without you, I am alone and friendless !

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Really, my dear, you are very pretty! Work would not suit you at all. We shall be able, I hope, to do better than that for yoU. As I said before, your story is so perplexing, that I can make nothing of it—there must have been something for this Stanmore to desert you—but we shall see—we shall see. We must have the advice of my cousin Thompson, who will presently be here.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Is she good—and kind—young?

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: She ! My dear, it's a he—a gentleman !

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Yes—did you never hear of gentlemen cousins ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, yes—yes—but—
sp.stage: Enter Miss Winch, L.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: If you please, ma'am, here is your cousin, Mr. Thompson. Walk in, if you please, Mr. Thompson.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke Of Endell, L.—Miss Winch curtseys, and goes off, L.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (to Madame A.) How do?

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (crosses, C, looking at Duke, significantly) Cousin Thompson, I am delighted to see yoU. (turning to Joanna) My dear—Cousin Thompson is a gentleman of great judgement and experience, on whose good-will you may rely.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (R.) It is no doubt kind of you, but—

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Hush! My niece, Cousin Thompson.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (e.) Ah! (raising eyeglass, and taking a steady look at Joanna) Um! (Madame A. looks anxiously at Duke, who nods) She'll do! I am delighted to see you, Miss—a—a—

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (C.) Joanna Arundelli!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ah, yes—I am quite delighted—perfectly charmed.
sp.stage: Enter Miss Winch, L.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Oh, if you please, ma'am, the hands don't know how to get on without yoU.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: How provoking! Cousin Thompson, will you excuse me a few moments?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Oh, certainly.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (taking Madame's arm) You will not leave me?

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (removing Joanna's arm) Don't be a fool! Tell Cousin Thompson your story, and he will advise. I shall be back soon.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: But I have no story, and no need of advice.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (crossing L.) Pooh ! pooh!
sp.stage: Nods significantly to Duke, and goes off, L., followed by Winch.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (with a bland smile, and his glass to his eye) Well, my dear, and what are your expectations ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (R.) Sir!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I want to know what are your expectations, my dear, that is all. You are a charming young creature, and I am only all amazement to know how on earth Arundelli found yoU. I think she said your friends were in the country ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I have no friend, sir, but Madame Arundelli.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Nay, pray include me, if you please ! Do not play the coy maiden, for I am the most liberal of men, as you will
find ; nor am I inconstant either, without good cause. Come, now, what do you say ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: If you please I—I should like to see my aunt. I—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Oh! she shall have every reason to be satisfied. There is really no need for consultation, for you are a charming, exquisite, adorable girl! I really and truly love you! There is a piquant innocence about you that is fresh as the perfume of early roses. I shall—I do admire you! mistress of my heart and fortune, there is nothing in all the world that your utmost caprice can long for that shall not be yours—the life that is before you, shall be a romance. I never loved till now! I hare been cold, indifferent, jaded, but now I love with all my heart !

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh! what can all this mean ? (calls) Aunt! Aunt! Oh! sir, let me pass, if you are a gentleman !

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I am a nobleman !

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I care not! I ask you but to prove you are a gentleman!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: My adorable girl—you shall be mine! and mine only!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Help! Aunt! Help!

p.stage: (Duke follows her round the table—Joanna, in her fright knocks over the table, she dashes open French window and shrieks "Help! help!" as Duke grasps her by the arm.—Music —tableau.
p.note: [No. 532, " Joanna attempting to escape from Cousin Thompson." ]

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This is carrying coquetry too far.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (looking through window' Save me ! save me!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (dragging her forward) Hush! you will attract notice from the street!

p.stage: Madame Arundelli enters hastily, L.—goes to and closes window.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Are you mad, girl—that you would draw observation to my house ? Are you mad, I say ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (C.) Ah! thank Heaven, you are here! You do not know, you cannot know this man!

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Hush ! hush !

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I will not be silent! I am slow of suspicion, but I feel that it is infamy to listen to him, or to breathe the air of his presence. Aunt, if this is the sort of protection you offer me, welcome the streets of London, even if I have to beg my daily bread.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (R.) I throw my fortune at your feet!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: And I despise it, sir, as I despise you!
sp.stage: Miss Winch enters hurriedly, L.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: A man rushing up stairs—a gentleman, I mean, ma'am, asking for Miss Cleveland. I couldn't stop him—he upset me on the stairs in a most indelicate manner—says he will see her.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Ah! help!

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Quick! (seizing Joanna) assist me, Winch! Drag her to my private cabinet—come!
sp.stage: Music—Madame Arundelli places her hand over Joanna'S mouth, who is dragged off, R.—the instant she is off, Charles Stanmore hurries on L.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (C.) Now, sir, why this intrusion ?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: (l. c.) I must and will see her! It was her voice I heard—it was her form I beheld—I will swear it! give her to me—I am in London searching for her, on authority of her relations.
sp.stage: Re-enter Madame Arundelli and Miss Winch, R.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: And pray, sir, who may you be, that you take upon yourself to rush into people's houses in this way, without the slightest knowledge of them, and without their leave ?

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am, perhaps the gentleman is mistaken, after all, and when he owns it, he may apologise. I don't know you, sir, and no relations have any right to claim me ; and if I choose, while playing at forfeits with my cousin, here, and Madame Arundelli, to go to the window, and cry " help " to get back my bracelet—for that was what I had to do—what is that to you, sir? (sticking out her elbows—advancing to Stanmore. and shaking her head in his face) Eh? eh? eh?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Yes, me! What then, sir!

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (shouting, L.) Minchin! take care of the spoons!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Well, well; in the excited state of my mind, it is possible that I may have been mistaken, and I must apologise to that elderly spinster for—

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Elderly spinster! Get out of the house you villain!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: (aside) I am not yet satisfied, and I will watch. Oh! Joanna, Joanna ! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: (shouting off) Minchin! watch the umbrellas in the passage. (turning to Duke) I warned your grace—you have spoiled all by being so precipitate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Have your own price—make your own arrangements —but that girl must be mine, if she costs me half my fortune.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: So she shall—for you are so liberal, there is no resisting you ; and I have a plan. The girl is pining for fresh air—there is a small parcel of choice lace to go to Lady Bedale's —Joanna shall be the bearer of it, on her return you must contrive—in short, the rest is for you to do. (crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Admirable ! You shall be well rewarded—doubt it not. Farewell! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: Oh, dear, all this agitation is too much for my delicate system—nothing will recover me but some bran—a little cordial, I mean.

sp.speaker: Miss W.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am, you are a poor dear angel.

sp.speaker: Madame A.
sp.p: I am afraid I am, Winch—I am afraid I am.

div.stage: Exit Miss Winch supporting Madame A., R.
Scene Third.—Street in London.
Enter John Butts and Susan Jenkins, L., arm in arm, both with their Sunday clothes on—John has an old fashioned watch chain, and immense bunch of seals, a thick oaken stick in his hand.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well, zooks and taters! this here Lunnun be the biggest place as ever I did see, and what surprises me above all, that it be all over houses. And I never seed such shops— and there's generally more than one man to keep one on 'em, for over almost every door there's Jones and Co., or Smith and Co., or something or other and Co. What a many people to be sure of the name of Co! I wonder if all them Mr. Co's are related to one another ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha ! Law, John, what a stupid gaby you are! Co is only a make believe—it means a Company.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Likely—but better monners, Susan, or I shan't keep company wi' you any longer—you a' gotten good brass to call me a gaby afore we're married, I think.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: La, John, it's only a playful expression.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh, zooks and taters ! you are playful is you—I don't fancy that, for playful women is like playful kittens—they scratches.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Well, don't be cross, John—give me a kiss.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What, out here in the street, wi' all the Lunnun chaps a looking at us ? No, dang it, I can't stand that neither.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
You have promised, John, to make me your lawful wife, and so I persuaded you to treat me up to London, because
I am acquainted with the renowned city, and can induct you to its galaxy of sparkling pleasure.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (whistling) Whew! Susan, is you a young woman, or is you a member of parlyment ? Hedgehogs and mangel wurzel! what is all them words about ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I mean, John, that I can introduce you to its intoxicating delights.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Intoxicating ! yes, I shouldn't wonder, for there be a nation sight of public houses in Lunnon—but I bean't inclined for a fuddle just now, thank'ee.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, dear, dear, John, you are remarkably obtruse.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Now, I say, Susan, doan't 'ee call names, I don't like it.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: 'Tisn't names, John, it's only the genteel words I picked up when I was in service in London.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Ah, well, if you picked 'em up, the sooner, I think, that you drop 'em agin, the better.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Well, John, to speak plain, as fashionable people say, I mean to show you the lions.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Why, zooks and taters! Do you think I've come up to Lunnon on'y just to see the wild beastes? I've seed 'em on'y t'other day—there was a menaggery down in our parts.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Menaggery! Oh, I give you up, John—you are incorrigible.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (in a passion) No, I bean't! I's a respectable farmer, and you may give up as soon as you like, for I tell 'ee what Susan, I wunt put up wi' no more of your dommed imperence ! If a man had said as much to me (taking off his hat and punching it) I'd a punched his head as flat as a pancake !

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Don't, John ! Don't spoil your new hat, or you'll have to buy another to be married in.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I won't be married at all! I'll have a divorce instead.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Perhaps that will come afterwards, (bursts into tears) How can you be so cruel? Oh, John Butts! John Bu-bu- bu—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh, dang it, Susan! if you begins to cry, I'm mollified directly.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (aside) I know that, it's only make-believe, (cries again) Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (whimpering) Now do give over, Susan, else I shall begin to bellow directly, do 'ee leave off, Susan ! Oh, ploughs and parsnips, Susy! I'll gi'ee onything if thee'lt ony gi' over.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (suddenly ceasing to cry) Will you, John ? will you let me buy that pretty dress I saw in the shop window yonder ?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p:
Eh? Oh dang it, Susan! you knows how to do it.
Well, zooks and taters! women be the most artful animals as ever I seed.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You said it would be a waste of money to buy it, and as we are going to be married, we both ought to be saving.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well, and I think so now.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You do, John, and musn't I buy it then, John? (begining to cry) you are the—the—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: No, no, stop, Susan! stop! Go and buy it—go and buy all the shop if you like, so long as you wont turn on that ere main again.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Come you with me, John, you can amuse yourself looking in at the shop window, while I am buying the dress.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What! and have some chap amuse himsen by cleaning out my pockets, as they did t'other day while I was a staring at the wax work.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: The thieves in London are dreadful.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Zooks and taters! that they is—they very nearly had my watch t'other day—that grandfeather gi' me—on'y it be so large that they couldn't lug it out o' my fob—it stuck by the way, and while the chap were a hauling at it, I let fly wi' my stick, and away he rolled into the gutter—and it's my opinion he'd ha' the headache for a week aterwards.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Well, wait here—I shan't be long, if the shop ain't full. You know I take a pleasure in obeying you, John, (aside) but only wait till we are married, and we'll soon see then who's master. Exit L.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (calling after her) Take care of your pockets, Susan ! I must look arter her, 'cause if she were robbed now, it would be so much loss when we are married. Zooks and taters! what a nation sight of people there be a walking about to be sure—I be's sure there can't be no room for 'em unless they sleep five or six in a bed.
sp.stage: Enter Major Edmonds, R., dressed shabbily.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: I am sure I shall be too late—can't see a clock about here, and my ticker has long ago been in the possession of an esteemed welative. Oh! here is an indiwidual. (advancing and touching John on the shoulder) My dear sir, excuse me, but—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (starting back) Keep off! or domme if I don't knock 'ee down.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Knock me down, eh? Oh yes—catch a weazel asleep! My good fwiend, I merely wish to know what's o'clock.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Eh ? (alarmed—takes his hat off and claps it over his bunch of seals') No, no, that wont do—I's up to your rigs— you know what's o'clock, well enough.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (aside) What a queer animal! (aloud) The fact is, my fwiend, I have an appointment with a lovely young lady—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (aside) Somebody he is going to rob, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: And I am afraid I shall be too late.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well, you won't get there no sooner by stopping here, you know.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Ha, ha! vewy good! catch a weazel asleep and—ha, ha ! I see—stwike me comical, you are a wag.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: A wag! perhaps I am—but I tell'ee what, if you don't go, you'll find my stick a-wagging about your head presently.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Oh! weally, I can't put up with this— (advancing towards John) and I must have—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: No, you shan't, nobody shall have it—it were grandfathers (shouting) here, purlice ! purlice!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Confound the fellow, it's lucky the police are never in the way when they are wanted. He is an innocent wustic I perceive, (to John) My good fwiend, I admiwr you exceedingly. (aside) here's a chance, catch a weazel—hem ! (aloud) My dear fellow, I am pwoud of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Be off! will'ee? I don't know'ee, and I don't want to.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: I was mewely about to say, that—that a tempowawy emergency—would—could you lend me half a cwown ?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I could!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (holding out his hand) Ah! thank you!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I could I say!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Thank you! I'm in lucks way, stwike me fortunate ! Thank you !

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: But I'm dommed if I do!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Oh! (John buttons up his coat) I see, catch a weazel asleep! (looking off, R.) Eh! yonder goes a young woman I have said a few tender things to—I think she's good for about eighteen pence. Here, Miss Swab! Catch a weazel asleep not to be done—stwike me uncomfortable ! Runs off, R.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (looking after him) Danged if I ain't had a wonderful escape—never see such a cut throat looking rascal in all my days!
sp.stage: Enter Joanna, L.. rather shabbily dressed, and carrying a small parcel.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p:
My aunt's designs are now but too plainly apparent, for the fine dress, having served it's turn, to wear in the presence of him she called her cousin, she has taken it from me, and given me this poor attire. And must I return to her house ! oh I where else can I go ? But this parcel which I am
to take. I must inquire my way. (going to John) Would you be kind enough to tell me—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (turning, seeing her, and retreating) Keep off! none of your Lunnon tricks, young 'ooman, they don't do wi'I; I've heerd of your games—you ain't a-going to hocuss I, I can tell' ee.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (hanging her head) Alas—alas!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: There now—she's going to cry—somebody has told her how to come over me. (advancing rather fearfully) Young 'ooman, if you be's really honest, I—I—(Joanna raises her head and looks at him) Eh ? (starting) surely I ought to know that face, for I never seed another like it; but it can't be—I ain't awake—it's a moral unposserbility.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (astonished) John Butts!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Miss Joanna ! Oh, oh, zooks and taters! (drops his stick and bursts out crying) Oh dear—oh dear! to see 'ee like this—you so good, so beautisome—it's enough to make anybody bad. Oh, dang it! how I should like to punch somebody's head.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, John, times are sadly changed with me.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I see they be, miss—and you that was such a lady —and that your uncle was so fond on.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, do not, John, in mercy do not.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Well, I won't; (wiping his eyes) but—(breaking out) Ploughshares and barley seed! (dashing his hat to the ground) It's enough to make a man—but here—here, I've gotten some o' the rhino, (hastily pulls out a leather bag full of money and thrusts it into her hand) Take that for the present—I ha' gotten some more at home ; and here—here—you shall ha' grandfeather's watch—I never thought to part wi it, but—(lugging at chain) Domn thee, come out, will 'ee!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (forcing him to take back his money) John, I knew you always for a noble-hearted fellow ; but pray take back your money—I cannot—at all events, not yet.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I understand; but if you won't have my money, I tell'ee what, Miss Joanna—you sees Susan Jenkins, you know her, in course. Well, we is a going to be married— she wouldn't let me have no peace till I said she might put up the bangs. And you—you, Miss Joanna, shall come and live wi' us, like a lady, as you is, or perhaps you mayn't like living wi' her as were once your servant—so I tell 'ee what, Miss Joanna I wont marry Susan at all—or I'll put it off for nine or ten years or so, and you shall come and live wi' me, all alone— there now!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Good John—we will talk of all that hereafter. I must not loiter longer here—evening draws on, and I have to deliver this parcel. Will you accompany me?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: 'Company you! Dang me if I ever leave you ony more. But where be's it you be's a-going to ?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: To Park Lane—do you know it ?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Lor, bless 'ee, not I! I never seed sich lanes as they ha' gotten in Lunnon—they be's all full o' houses.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It is to a Lady Bedale, that I am going.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What, to a real, live lady ? Lor, come along then! we'll find it, never fear—and while you goes into the house, I'll lie down on the step o' the door, and keep a sharp look out, like my dog Towser does, outside his kennel.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Come, then, my kind friend.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Stop, let's get my hat, and my walking stick, (picks them up) and we'll talk over matters by the way—for dang me if you shall be without a good home while John Butts has got a pound in his old leather bag.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (taking John's arm) Heaven will one day reward you for this goodness.
sp.stage: As they are going, arm in arm, R., Susan enters, L., carrying a large parcel before her—she gives a furious start—John turns and sees her.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, gracious! John—John! what does this dreadful vision mean?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Don't bother me now, young 'ooman, Zooks and taters! don't you see I'm 'ticlarly engaged.
sp.stage: (walks off with Joanna, R., Susan stares after them amazed —then her arms drop, and the large parcel falls to the ground,

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, oh ! I'm very ill—I want to faint, and I can't, for I don't see a blessed soul to catch me ! Oh, the monster ! and next Sunday would have been the last time of asking. It's all the fault of those horrid draper's young men—they kept me so long talking ; and they looked so nice, done up all in black and white ; and now, I shall look blue, for I have lost my young man. Oh, oh, oh ! (crying) And so much trouble I had, too, to catch him; and now he's broke loose. Oh! if I only had hold of the nasty hussy that's unwiggled him from me—I'll— I'll—oh, oh, oh ! (crying)
sp.stage: Enter Major Edmonds, R.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Bless my soul! what's the matter? don't, young woman—you'll distuwb the whole neighbourhood. (Susan bellows) Don't, I tell you—you'll be shot! People will think there's an unlimited number of cats in the gutter—stwike me uneasy!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (looking up, and ceasing to cry) Why, bless me, it's Major Edmonds!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Eh ? you know me ? (aside) One of my victims, perwhaps. (aloud) I am glad to find you have left off cwying.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: No, I haven't, (breaks out again)

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (stopping his ears) Oh—murder! Will you be quiet, just for one moment?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Certainly! (suddenly ceasing) How is it that you are in London, Major Edmonds ?

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Business! to see Miss Lisa Selby, if I can ; I want some money from her—she is under gweat obligations to me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (breaking out again) Oh ! John! John!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: John! John! one might as well be in a dun-jon, as to hear this wow ! Will you stop for another moment?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (suddenly ceasing) By all means.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: How do you happen to know me ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I was servant at Cleveland Hall, when you used to come there.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Oh, indeed! You are a pwetty girl, will you take a small walk with me, my love ?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (bursting out again) No, no, never, certainly not, no, no, no ! (suddenly ceasing, and taking his arm) Yes, I will!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: That's wight, a—hem! 'pon my soul, I am ashamed to ask, but, pecuniawy disappointments—hem! could you lend me half a cwown?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (producing her purse) With pleasure, Major.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (aside) All wight! catch a weazel asleep, and— (she gives him half a crown) Thank you my angel! (aside) I'll make a little love to her, and then borwow another.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Would you have the goodness, Major, to carry that small parcel for me ?

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Small parcel! hem! (lifts it from ground) Ah! well, one comfort it isn't heavy, (puts it under his arm)

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh! (with a half scream) don't do that, Major. By the bye, people say you are not a Major!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Do they ? ha, ha! malice, my love, malice—catch a weazel asleep, you know.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, dear, you have crushed it quite flat, you must carry it gently ; hold your arm up, there, (lying dress across his arms) There, (taking his arm) that's the way you must carry it—it is so nicely cut out.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (aside) And a pwetty figure I shall cut—never mind, there's another half cwown or two, on the woad.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: It's a new dress—I bought it to—to—because, Jo— Jo—John— (roaring loudly) oh, oh !

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Oh! dem it! she's bweaking out in a fwesh place.

div.stage: Exeunt L.
Scene Fourth.—Mansion in Park Lane. Handsome apartment, sumptuously furnished—ottomans, consoles, vases, &c.
Lisa, in elegant evening dress, discovered at table, her face buried in her hands—Music—after a pause, she looks up.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I have attained the wealth and splendour for which I pined, but am I happy ? No! Joanna—where'er thou art, whatever thy wretchedness—more tranquilly dost thou sleep than she who toiled and sinned to plunge thee into misery! (rises) But I will pursue the course I have begun—I will not, if I can avoid it, fall from my high estate, and so become the world's mockery ! My state, supported by stolen wealth, surrounded by suitors whom I despise, while he whom I so madly love, rejects me with all my riches, and lavishes his adoration on a poor, penniless girl. I have been taught to think that wealth can purchase every joy. It is a lie! for is it not powerless to win me now the only heart I prize ?
