There is, too, a never ceasing fear around, about me—weighing down, amidst the gayest throng, the spirits that should be buoyant. The happiness sought by guilt, is but illusion—each step I take, 1 dread the avalanche that would overwhelm me.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Bedale, R., handsomely dressed.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: My love, there is a shabby looking man—the servants can't get rid of him—he insists on seeing you—says his name is Croker.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (starting) Ah !

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Croker! what a horrid name! I shall make him go—for of course we don't want a croker here.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No, no, Lady Bedale, I will see him—I—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: My dear, you are agitated! Who then, is this Croker?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Lady Bedale, you have promised that you would not be curious—that you would not seek to pry into the mystery which I have freely confessed surrounds me.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Very true, my love ; your wealth has restored me to the society from which I thought myself for ever banished— and, certainly, no scruples of mine—but this man — this Croker?
sp.stage: Enter Croker, R.

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: That's me—I'm Croker—" Crowbar Croker," they call me. I'm an honest lawyer—ugh, ah—bow-wow, ugh ! what do you think of that? (crosses, c.) Miss Selby—ah, um! —must speak to you—old lady, go away !

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Old lady !

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Venerable, but not respectable—eugh, ah, bowwow—get out! eugh!
sp.stage: Lady Bedale flounces off, R.—Lisa sinks into chair, h.

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Ah, um! ain't you well? Look here! (holding letter) My client, Sir John Cleveland, has written to me—um —thinks that you are at my house—that I am helping you to search for his other niece—eugh, um! don't understand it— says he gave you a letter—you have never been to me, you know—says he shall be in London in a day or two, to see how the matter goes on—what matter? eugh ! um! something is the matter, I am sure of that! he wants to know about his lost lamb; but I know that Lady Bedale is an old cat—eugh! um! bow-wow! eugh ! (wheezing)

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (rising, greatly agitated—aside) Oh! the ruin that I dreaded is approaching—how to avert it?

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Well! um! ah ! don't talk to yourself, talk to me, eugh ! um ! bow-wow ! eugh ! (coughing and wheezing)

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Mr. Croker, to-morrow at two o'clock I will be at your office, and—and—will arrange this affair with you, and, if you—if you would condescend to be my solicitor, and—and to accept of a fee of a thousand guineas for—

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Bribery! Ah! um! Was sure there was something wrong—won't do—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Two thousand !

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Oh! ee eugh !

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Four thousand!

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: You want to know my price ; for what sum I will betray, in some gross way, my old client, Sir John Cleveland ? Oh, um—go to the devil! Ah, eugh, bow-wow!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: But you will wait till two to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Yes; that won't make much difference—but I must know then, the game you are playing, or I shall be sure to find you out, and then so much the worse for you; you may wriggle and twist, but you are caged and caught. Bow-wow, eugh! my name is Croker—that's enough, to those that know me—bow-wow! I shall see you to-morrow.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Bedale, R.
sp.p: Get out of the way, old lady! (crosses, R.) To-morrow! tomorrow ! (looking at Lady Bedale) Ah, eugh—pussy cat! Bow-wow, eugh! Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The old hog! eugh! My dear, the visit of that savage has disturbed you—you look ill.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (with affected composure) Oh! no, he merely called on a little business that—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (aside) That's false, I know. But never mind, she has still about two hundred thousand pounds at her bankers.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (severely) Why did you return, Lady Bedale, when you knew that I was not alone ?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I really thought that horrid Croker was gone. (aside) That's a thumper! (aloud) I came to tell you that a young person is here from Madame Arundelli's with the patterns of the lace that— (pointedly) but perhaps you are too troubled now to bother about such trifles ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (with an effort) Troubled? certainly not, wherefore? let her come in.
sp.stage: Music. —Joanna enters R., crosses to a, curtseys to Lisa, who, at that moment, turns towards Joanna, their eyes meet— Chord—Joanna drops parcel.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (joyfully) Lisa!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (aside—greatly agitated) Joanna!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Lisa ! dear Lisa! my cousin ! companion of my childhood—dear friend of my girlish days—oh ! how is it that I see you here, surrounded with so much splendour? Oh ! tell me, is he well—my dear uncle—tell me, is it possible that he will be here—is this to be the blessed end of all distress? Oh, Lisa ! Lisa ! in mercy speak to me.

p.stage: (Lady Bedale is staring in astonishment, n.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (coldly) Lady Bedale, is this young person a lunatic ?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Eh! well—yes—I should'nt at all wonder !

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Lisa, can this be? Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I never saw you in my life before.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (shrinking back) Oh! say not that! surely you are Lisa. The look—the tone! Oh, Lisa ! you are jesting with me. Say that you are—speak, dear Lisa, oh! speak to me.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Begone ! I know you not!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Good Heavens! (turning to Lady Bedale) Oh, tell me—is not the name of this young lady, Selby ?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ye—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (loudly, and with a stem glance at Lady Bedale.) No !

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Not! then sight and mind are surely failing me. Oh ! Heaven help and protect me.
sp.stage: Music —Joanna gazes searchingly into the face of Lisa, who returns the look with one of cold severity—Joanna shudders and staggers off, R., Lisa sinks into chair.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (picking up parcel, and placing it on table) There is something very mysterious in all this, for that young woman was as sensible as I am, and of course your name is Selby—

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (rising) Lady Bedale, I will soon make you my confidant—will tell you all; and now leave me, leave me, for I have need to reflect—ay, and to act.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p:
Very well, my love, (aside) There will be a smash and a crash, soon ; I am sure of that. I am sadly afraid her great heap of money was not honestly come by; and— But
never mind, I have saved something worth while, thank goodness! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Monti! he only can save me now. I must instantly seek him—
sp.stage: Enter Monti, R.—chord.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: You need not, Lisa, he is here. You are agitated— you tremble—wherefore? You have no cause for fear.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Not ? ruin surrounds me every way, and only you can rescue me.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: And I will do so. Joanna has been here.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ah! you know?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Yes; know too, that ere long she will be beyond the power of doing you harm—will cross your path no more.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: You will not slaughter— Oh ! I am not yet prepared for that.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Fear not, her life is safe.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Thanks for that; but I have more to tell—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I know that you would say. Croker has been here—you have never delivered your letter of introduction; and Sir John has written to him, making inquiries, and announcing his intention of being in London within a few days.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes, yes; how could you know all this ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Nothing can escape me.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes, yes ! you are powerful, and you will save me.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I will! (she clasps her hands joyfully) Desperate perils must be encountered by desperate means. Croker must be silenced.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ah, yes! offer him any sum. (he smiles) But Sir John—should he arrive in London!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: He will not!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: He must be stopped.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Stopped ! you do not mean—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Murder him! Well, to save you, I may even commit a murder, since I have already plunged into forgery on your account.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Yes, the bankers wrote to inform Sir John of your heavy drafts on his account—I, no matter how, contrived to intercept that letter.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: You did!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Ay ; and returned one, seemingly written by Sir John, which assured the bankers that all was well, and bade them yield to you that you all should command.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Already then, you have saved me from destruction ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: And will again. Go on, and fear not. Your star has not yet culminated—you are, as yet, but entering on your glorious career!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh, that I were but assured of that!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: You may be. Confide in me—hitherto have I in aught failed you?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No, oh, no ! but—but for all this, you will require something more of me ?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Yes, Lisa, yes—we serve, and are useful to each other.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Is it more money? Be moderate, Monti, the sum at my disposal, were it ten times the amount, would soon vanish before such drafts as you make upon it. You have already had seventy thousand.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Not my fair proportion. But, at present I shall not ask you for more money, but jewels—for four and twenty hours, as was our compact. You do not procure them fast enough. You have opportunities for obtaining the most priceless in the land.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I borrow, where'er 'tis possible—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: But you neglect the chances where you might borrow without the consent of the owner, and replace again—and none be a whit the wiser.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I cannot, and I will not do that—I will not, as I have told you, become a common thief.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (with a sneering laugh) And yet you have robbed of a large sum, your loving, doting, foolish old uncle.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Robbed!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Oh! I beg pardon—appropriated is a genteeler word! Do my bidding Lisa, or, in an instant, and in the height of your glory, stricken with disgrace—crushed with infamy—you will shriek and grovel at my feet.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Mercy! do not—I shudder in every limb—I will obey you in everything.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Then you are safe; but, remember, that at every moment of your life, you stand upon the brink of an abyss; and that you will surely topple over, whenever it shall please me to withdraw my protecting arm. Forget not that, and so, farewell! Music—Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Yes, I am in his power, and must obey his behests; and he, alone, can save me. Oh ! I hate him with an intensity that knows no bounds. But vainly do I groan—vainly do I writhe and struggle, for I am his bonded slave. He has made me what I now am ; and by a breath he could scatter the fabric of my new existence to the winds. No, no, I dare not defy him, for I am his—his—his—body and soul, are all his own. Music—Exit, L.

div.stage: Scene Fifth.—Street—Night,(2nd grooves)
Music— John Butts hurries on, R.—and looks every way.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh! zooks and taters ! gone—gone—can't find her nowheres. What a marcy it would be if somebody would come and kill me—I desarves it. What will Miss Joanna think of me, arter all my promises ? Oh! I've a great mind to knock mysel' on the head wi' my stick. Eh ? be that her? (runs and looks off, L.) No, it be a perlisman. While I wur sitting on the step o' the house, a man fell down opposite—they said he wur in a fit; but nobody seemed to care, so I went to help the poor critter up ; and as soon as I got him on his feet, he lugged grandfeather's watch out o' my fob, and run away like mad; and ever so many chaps knocked me about, and pushed my hat over my eyes ; and when I got it up again, and could see—dang me if there wur a soul in sight nowhere. Oh ! Lunnun be a awful place. Eh? dang it—there's Miss. Joanna, (runs to R.) No! (shaking his head) it's a Hitalian wi' a barrel organ. And then, when I came to my thoughts agin, I run to the door and hammered away wi' my stick, and axed for Miss Joanna; and they told me she wur gone, and said they'd lock me up ; but I didn't wait for that, and—eh ? (turning towards L.) I be sure that be her yonder by the gashlight. Oh! I be's so glad— Miss Joanna! Miss Joanua ! oh lud! oh lud ! Runs off, L.
sp.stage: Enter Duke Endell, R.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis clear she has escaped me—yet how? she has not passed this way on her return—of that I'm certain.
sp.stage: Monti has entered, R. 2 E., and advanced to the Duke's side.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: The girl for whom you wait will presently be here ; and I, and only I can place her securely in your power.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ah! how know you—?

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: No matter! her friends would richly reward him who would bring her back to their arms.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: That must not be. I, too, can reward.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I know it. I have an interest in keeping the girl from her home—I have an influence over her. Agree to my terms, and she is yours—refuse, and she is lost to you for ever.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And those terms—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: A thousand pounds, and the immediate removal of the girl from this country.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Give her to me, and I will double the reward you ask.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: And will take her, at once, from England?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: You may safely trust me; I will, as I have before done, throw her into a mesmeric trance, and she will follow you, and will be powerless in your hands, (crosses c.) She is coming ! I but go to bid your coachman draw up to the spot. Accost and detain her with a few words till my return.
sp.stage: Exit L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, I will take her abroad to sunny Italy, and she will be all my own—my own !
sp.stage: Enter Joanna, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Vainly have I lingered and searched—he has not rejoined me. What can have happened? willingly, I am certain, John Butts would not desert me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (advancing, L.) My charming creature, do I meet you once again?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Ah! I see it plainly now—poor John has been entrapped. Let me pass you, sir, or I will shriek for help.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Nay, why shrink from one who so passionately loves you?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Villain! I will go my way. (crossing to L.)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (grasping her) No! by Heaven, you shall not again escape me.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Help! help! (Music—they struggle) Will no friendly hand be raised to protect me ?

p.stage: John Butts runs on, L.2.E., and knocks the Duke down with cudgel.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (looking down at him) There! now you'll keep your paws off another time, won't you ? Dang it! how his head has bruised my stick, surely. Lord, my dear, I be's so glad to see 'ee again, (hugs her, and then shrinks back abashed) I axes pardon! don't 'ee be afeared, miss—I be's an innocent chap, I assure 'ee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (rising) Villain! this attack upon my life shall not go unpunished, (seizing John) Police! police !

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Don't 'ee stir a single step, miss, from where 'ee be— I'll soon get rid of this fellow! Let go, you' sir, do 'e hear ? Let go, or dommed if I don't gi' 'ee another topper.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (shouting) Police! police!

p.stage: (music—They struggle, and Duke drags John off, R. 1 E.

sp.stage: Enter Monti, L. 2 E., and crosses at back to R.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p:
Oh, Heaven! should he come to harm on my account—at any risk, I will not desert him. (Music—Going, R. —she encounters Monti, and shrinks back alarmed—he looks
fixedly into her eyes—greatly terrified) That man again! his gaze fascinates—petrifies me!
sp.stage: (Monti advances to her, and waves his arms, (music, piano, tremuloso, tell they are off stage) after two or three passes, Joanno's head droops—he walks round her and remains, L.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Joanna, I will that you should follow me!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (in a trance) I must—I must!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Come, then, come !
sp.stage: Monti backs off, L., waving his hands, and Joanna slowly follows him—Music agitato—John Butts runs on, R. U. E.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: (looking about) Gone again ! Oh, zooks and taters! this be too much. I knocked that chap down again, and bolted from the purlice, and now—but she must be gone that way, and I'll find her, or I'll die—dang me if I don't! so here goes. Where be 'ee ? where be 'ee ?
sp.stage: Running off, L. 1 E.—Susan meets him,

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, John! my dear John !

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Dom thee ! stand out of the way!
sp.stage: Pushes her on one side and runs off, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh! oh! the villain! But I see it now—the sights of London have turned his brain. As sure as can be, he's got a fit of lunacy. Nice job I have done for myself in bringing him here—to lose a husband in such times as these, when they are so particularly scarce. And that wretch of a Major, too, just as we turned the corner, he run away from me, and took my new dress with him, and left me in such a dreadful state of horror, that I hadn't sufficient presence of mind to call murder.
sp.stage: Enter Major Edmunds, L.,whistling—stops suddenly on seeing Susan.

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Hem! Unpleasant meeting!—awkward—vewy ! Never mind—catch a weazel asleep and shave his eyebrows.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (who has been gasping) I couldn't speak before, or else I would; you rascal! swindler ! Where is my dress?

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Don't be uneasy, my love, it is quite safe.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, thank goodness for that! But where is it ?

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Where ? oh! hem ! Why—it's with my uncle.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: (starting) Your uncle ! You don't mean the—the—

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Yes I do ! My necessities dwove me to the deed. You refused to lend me another half-a-cwown, and so the new dwess went up for seven and six.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And it cost me one pound eleven ! Oh, you villain ! I'll lock you up!

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: No you won't—for to pwove to you that I intend to behave handsomely in the matter—there's the ticket. Stwike me liberal! (giving it)

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, you vagabond! you—

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: (looking off, R.) Oh, Lord! here's the police! Catch a weazel asleep—and stwike me particularly scarce!
sp.stage: Runs off, L.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why, he's gone ! Ah! ah! ah! (screaming violently)
sp.stage: Enter Two Policemen, R.

sp.speaker: 1st. Policeman.
sp.p: Come, I say, you gal, don't make that row.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: There he goes ! Ah ! (screams)

sp.speaker: 1st. Policeman.
sp.p: Oh, I see, you're drunk again.

sp.speaker: 2nd Policeman..
sp.p: Lock her up once more.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: There he goes ! (screams)

sp.speaker: 1st. Policeman.
sp.p: Policeman. Yes, and here you go—to the station house.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I won't go—I won't—ah! John—John— ah ! ah!

div.stage: Music They hurry her off struggling and screaming, R.
Scene Sixth.— Willesden Lane.
Moonlight. Music. Monti discovered, C, his arms folded a heavy riding whip in his hand.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: 'Tis down this lane that every night Croker, after having left the omnibus, walks to his home. The friend who each evening leaves town with him, branches off to his own home at yonder turning, (pointing off R.) so that when Croker shall reach the spot where now I stand, he will be alone. One way, or another, he must be silenced; and should it need to be the other way, the deed may be done in safety. My horse brought me here swiftly—he is tethered to a tree near this, and will as quickly take me back again. Half measures will not do, where there is so much at stake. Lisa's fortune, and consequently mine, must not thus be blasted, (listening R.) Hark ! what was that ?

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: (without, as if at some distance) Good night, my friend!

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: (without) Ah, eugh, good night! Bow-wow, eugh!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Tis he! He comes—he comes—it may be, never to depart alive!
sp.stage: Music—Monti walks steadily up stage, and takes his stand, C, as before—after a pause.

Croker, in a shabby great coat, and carrying a large cotton umbrella, enters, R. 1 E., and walks leisurely up stage, his head down, as if in thought, till he arrives at the spot where Monti is standing.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Delighted to see you, Mr. Croker!

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: (looks up and starts) Eh? eugh, bow-wow ! I don't know yoU.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Mr. Croker, I wish to speak to you on some business of much importance to yourself and others. I am a neighbour of yours, and have walked down the lane in the hope of meeting yoU.

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Then you may walk back again—I never speak of business out of office.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Consent to become the man of business to Miss Selby, and name you terms.

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Oh! that's it, is it ? Hang me if I didn't think so. Ha, ha, heugh! Bow-wow! eugh You only waste your own time and mine too—get out of my way !

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Not yet—you must listen to me.

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Eh, what? Eugh, bow-wow! You don't mean to obstruct me, do you ? That is an assault, sir, I can tell you, if you don't know it, an assault in law, sir!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: I do know it. I tell you, Mr Croker, that by fair means or foul, you shall be stopped from writing to Sir John Cleveland tomorrow. You may make your fortune by abstaining—as a reasonable man would do—you may lose your life by your obstinacy.

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: My life!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Yes, your pitiful life !

sp.speaker: Croker.
sp.p: Help ! mur—

div.stage: Music,—With a sudden bound Monti grasps Croker by the throat—Croker raises his umbrella—Monti strikes him with his whip, and wounds him—after a terrible struggle, they fall together—Monti gets Croker under, kneels upon his chest, and taking a handkerchief from his own pocket, places it around Croker'S neck, and grasps it tightly with both hands.—tableau. [No. 537 " Death struggle between Monti and Croker."
Scene Seventh.—Handsome Chamber. (1st grooves.)
Enter Lady Bedale, Sir John Cleveland, and Dr. Meadows, L.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: (C.) You swear, then, to be silent?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: (R.) I have sworn, Sir John, solemnly sworn. Oh! dear—who could have thought—

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p:
Your ladyship must have known that she had no just right to such vast wealth. But, aid us in our present scheme, preserve the strictest silence, avoid the slightest hint by word or
look, of my presence in London, and you shall be suffered to retain the money given you by my unworthy niece.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh, Sir John ! I am deeply grateful. I should have been more particular—but, you see, Lisa found me so very poor, and poverty—

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Is a great temptation to do evil. Well, well, be silent and discreet, and your share in this disreputable matter shall never be known to the fashionable world you hold in so much awe.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh, thanks, Sir John! I am, I know, a blighted lily, and uncheered by the rays of fashionable life should soon wither and die. (aside) It hasn't been such a bad thing for me, after all—but the infamy of Lisa's conduct is most atrocious.Exit, R .

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Lisa's puzzling silence is now too terribly accounted for. The ungrateful, heartless monster! In some way, I feel assured, she has been the prime mover of all, of which poor darling Joanna was accused.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: There can be little doubt of that, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: My blessed child ! I tremble to think of what she must have endured and suffered. Alas! alas! unable to bear the calamity that has befallen her, should she have perished by her own hands! Oh ! what horror is in the thought!

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Do not fear that, Sir John. Joanna is a good, and religious girl. No, no, she would not do that.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Thank you, doctor, for those comforting words. Thanks to you, also, that, under Heaven, restored me to somewhat of my former strength—and have given me renewed energy, that I may hunt through the world for my darling child, and punish the guilty wretch who has so ungratefully, so vilely, repaid me for all the tender care that I for years have lavished on her.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Talk not so loudly, Sir John; walls have ears, and you know that you are dead, (smiling)

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Yes, yes! When Charles Stanmore's letter informed us how Lisa was proceeding, you persuaded me to suffer you to write to Lisa, that unable to endure longer, the shock I had received from Joanna's loss, I had suddenly expired. But it seems to me a trifling with heaven, and I now regret having yielded to the mockery.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Nonsense, my friend—our motive is good. Supposed dead, you will now be enabled easily to unravel matters, that otherwise might have continued inextricable. But, come, let us to our hiding place

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p:
I only want to find my poor Joanna! Large as is the sum of which that jade, Lisa, has despoiled me—I have still
ample riches left. I can forget all—forgive everything—if once again by Heaven permitted to hold my dear, lost darling to my heart! Exeunt r

div.stage: Scene Eighth.—Handsome Chambers., elegantly furnished —folding doors, C.—doors, R. 2 E. and L. 2 E.
Enter Lisa, hastily, R., an open letter in her hand.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Dead, dead—he is dead! Sir John Cleveland is dead. and I am free from future danger—shall no longer live in fear, Who shall now call me to account for that which I have done ? Oh! I shall henceforth walk abroad without that insupportable weight at my heart—shall no longer tremble at every sound. And Monti! ha, ha, ha ! he has lost his power over me. Boldly now, the slave may spurn her master!
sp.stage: Music—Monti hurries on, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Now, Lisa, speak ! Have I any more work to do? Speak ! am I not relieving your path for you ? Do I scruple or stop at anything ? Do I not wade through blood to serve you?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Blood!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Ay, blood! The old lawyer is dead ! To save you, I have slain him!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Horrible!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: What say you ? And was it not for you that I— but never more—oh ! never more ! His glassy eyes, even now, are staring into mine — his throat seems even now within my hands—his death gurgle still ringing in my ear. Oh! never more! never more! (sinking into chair) Give me wine, for I am heart-sick—no, not that, that cannot be, since I have no heart—but brain-sick, almost to madness—and it's no wonder—for after all, I am but human! No more blood! no more! come what will, on Sir John Cleveland I will not lay a finger,

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Sir John is already beyond your reach—he is dead.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (starting to his feet) Dead? how—when?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (giving him letter) Read, and learn how useless the murder you have committed.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (having glanced over letter) Oh, curses, withering, and eternal curses on the madness that drove me to the deed.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ay! Now, Monti, you are in my power! 'Tis your turn, now, to be a slave—you are at my mercy, and when you fail sufficiently to cringe, and crawl before me, that instant I denounce you— I give you to the scaffold!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Fiend! fiend!

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No, I am simply that which you have made me— a Woman of the World !

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: On the scaffold I shall never perish! I am at all times prepared 'gainst that. Revolt, endeavour to betray me, and it's yourself that would ascend the scaffold. Have you forgotten that in everything you have been my accomplice. Did you not stand by, when in her mesmeric trance, Joanna dropped the poison into her uncle's drink ? Is not Joanna, now within my power—to be produced by me at any moment I shall choose? And is not the will still extant which makes her heiress, which gives her all—and how would you then escape the penalty of your robbery, if not, Sir John's, of her wealth ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I would die! It would but be a pang, and then peace !

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Peace, for you! No, no, Lisa, you dare not die! And I hare not yet told you all. The jewels which you borrowed to lend to me, I have kept. You have given back to their owners false ones which my skill enabled me to render undistinguishable from the originals—I have but to proclaim that, and then, Lisa, what think you would your fashionable friends say to their new found votary.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Oh ! entrapped—entangled beyond all hope of extrication.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Even so! You see, you have not yet shaken off my yoke—I am still your master—you are still my slave.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No, Monti, no; we will be equals—friends.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Friends! psha! I tell you, Lisa, I am, and will be your master. Ah ! you thought, did you, that Sir John's death had freed you from my power—you were, you see, mistaken. (grasping her arm) Down—down, then, to your knee, and crave of me mercy and forgiveness, (forcing her down)

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (breaking from him) No, I will not! I will no longer live in thrall and dread—I will be free, or nothing—will denounce you, though I die!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Ah! say you so? are you, indeed, so resolute? You shall die, but not denounce me. I did not think to shed more blood, but since you will have it so, why be it so. (drawing small dagger)

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Ah, villain! you have sealed your doom.
sp.stage: Music—Lisa is hurrying off, L.—Monti pursues and brings her back—they struggle—he seizes her by her hair and raises his dagger to strike, when the folding doors are suddenly dashed open, and discover Sir John and Dr. Meadows—Monti and Lisa see Sir John—Monti drops the dagger, and both stagger back, utterly appalled.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: (L.) Living! he is living!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: (R.) He has heard all—I am lost.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Yes, atrocious villain! yes, nought now remains for you, except to die; but, my Joanna—it can no further serve your hellish purpose now to keep her from me; then give her back to me—oh—give her once more to these doating arms.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Say, Lisa, shall it be so ?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No ; let me not in every way be baffled—I have lost all else; but, leave me, at least, revenge!

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: As I expected. Sir John, I cannot, if I would; restore to you your niece—she has become the victim of the Duke of Endell.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh, infamy! infamy and despair; and I have caused this ruin. But where is she ? tell me, do not keep from me the hope to rescue, and avenge her.

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: Vain hope ; ere this she has quitted England.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh, misery—misery !
sp.stage: Enter Charles Stanmore, hastily, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir John—Sir John—take comfort—Joanna—

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh! what of her? speak! in mercy, speak!
sp.stage: Joanna rushes on, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Here! she is here, dear uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: My darling! she is mine again—again! (embrace)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Conducted by John Butts, that noble-hearted fellow, I overtook the Duke of Endell, as he was about to bear Joanna on board his yacht, rescued her, and left the duke senseless on the ground ; and oh, sir, was it not a happy fate, that it should be mine to rescue her, for she has forgiven me all my former cruelty.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh! yes, yes—all must be forgiven, now I have my child again. Take her, Charles, take her. (Joanna goes to Charles I am so happy that I can pardon even thee, Lisa ; but never let me see you more.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I scorn your mercy. I am no longer the child you tolerated in your sight, and condescended to rear, while all your love was given to her. 'Twas your partiality which first dropped envy into my heart-—that vice was the parent of all the others that have since found place within my soul—drove me to him, (pointing to Monti) who made me the wretch you now behold me.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: (going to her) Lisa, I forgive you all—dear Lisa.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p:
Away! I hate you now, as I have ever hated you. From my childhood I have loathed you, for you ever stood between me and the love I coveted. Curse—oh, curse you all.
(Joanna turns away shuddering) But I have had some revenge —I have rioted in what should have been you yours—have cast to the winds your hoped-for wealth—ha, ha, ha ! I have not lost all—the memory of that still is left to me—ha, ha, ha! So now do with me as you will, for I—I—ah ! ah ! (suddenly places her hand upon her heart, and falls back into the arms of Dr. Meadows, who bears her off, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Oh! how little did I think that I was nourishing such a viper in my bosom. For you, miscreant—

sp.speaker: Monti.
sp.p: For me—death! but not upon the scaffold ! (throws phial to the ground) I carry now my doom within me. The stake I played for, I have lost, and so, farewell! and do not think I die repentant. No ! were the same to do again, I'd do it. Now give me to the officers of the law, I shall not seek to avoid them—a few minutes hence, and they can but secure my corse. Exit, L. 2 B.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, uncle! what mean these horrors ?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Hush, darling, hush !
sp.stage: Enter John Butts and Susan Jenkins, L. 2 E., arm in arm.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Oh, zooks and taters! on'y let me get out of Lunnon —and if ever I shews my nose in it again, I'm dommed!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Hush, John, hush! you musn't swear before ladies!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: I don't care ! Think o' poor Miss Joanna! There ia nout but villany in Lunnon. Susan's been in the Stationhouse, and I've lost grandfeyther'swatch.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Well, my brave fellow, to make you amends, you shall have your farm rent free for the remainder of your existence.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Eh? Shall I ? Oh, lord, Susan! dost hear?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Yes, John, it penetrated to my olfactories.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Rent free! Oh, lord! rent free! he, he, he! Oh, zooks and taters!
sp.stage: Enter Doctor Meadows, R.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Lisa!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: What of her? Speak!

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: She has burst a blood vessel—she is dead !

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Peace to her guilty soul! Joanna, my darling, be thankful that you are single minded, truthful, and loving, for that is the right wisdom ot heaven and of the heart—and she who with religion, meekness, charity, and love, fulfils her earthly mission—is the truest and wisest Woman of the World.

div.stage: Charles. Joanna. Sir John. Susan. Sir John. Dr. M
